I haven’t any idea whether such is the case in the present
series. My own personal reaction would be much the same as
yours. My working opinion, however, remains thesame. I think
the program should be considered by the duly appointed program
committee before it is offered.
Indeed we have offered the UN and UNESCO programs. I’m not
certain they are quite in the same class as governmental
administrative agencies. However, they may well present the
same problem^ in the future. I also think the board and the
committee should consider this type of program and how it
should fit into the future network picture.
I am not against programs on subjects that can be
considered controversial. Far from it! It is only that I
think some democratic process should exist in the organization
to decide such issues, to insure that the association is
placed in any given position with its eyes open and not
because of personal beliefs or whims of mine, not? Jim’s, nor,
indeed, yours.
3. The Los Angeles County Museum Concerts. Talk about
liaison! It is my firm belief that Morton Levine, Bill Sener,
a»d J. Caesar Petrillo have no business whatsoever soliciting
the network stations in an effort to promote their program!
Which points up a very serious organizational problem which I
should like to discuss later.
On the previous L.A. series, nine stations accepted it,
at least one of which dropped it before it was half over. I
have nothing against the Los Angeles Museum nor against any
ofathe musicians in that area. If we can fcsfc get some information
on the series, if they are decently recorded, and if enough
of them are done to guarantee a flow of programs I am all for
putting it before the program committee. Now here is case,
where some committee recommendation should decide which of
several music programs should be offered. We can’t offer them
all, so who is to decide? In this particular case the
mechanics of the thing would have to be straightened out before
it could even be considered.
4. Network facilities. We may have been wrong in deciding
to have the U of Illinois Recording Service do our duplicating.
However, both Jim and I, working closely at the scene, felt
that it was the only possible solution. We did think about the
problem rather extensively. I don’t know of any better way to
arrive at such answers.
If we hadn’t followed this course we wouldn’t be doing
much duplicating. We have not yet had the equipment and the
personnel to do this job. On the pooled basis currently in
operation we get the best possible service at the iacaxjE lowest
possible cost. I am of the opinion that in the long run some
similar xxxxkx system will be the answer. As long as trained
operating and maintenance personnel already exist, and can
devote as much time as we require to our work I see no reason
to hire and attempt to train new people. We have received
nothing but wholehearted cooperation and service. Experience
